But when you have a packed place, you guys need to hustle and get rid of your shit face. 

We ordered 12 drink (same) specials at once because we have 12 people in our party, plus we stood there for 20 minutes before he would even acknowledge you. The bartender was throwing major attitude and said that we couldn't do that and completely ignored us. What?!!?!?  We just continued to stand there and he finally mixed the drinks after standing there for another 15 minutes. We watched him slowly move about the bar and had ZERO sense of urgency. He could care less...

I've encountered this bartender before and he is wound up tight. He's tall and has got longer brown curly hair with a beard. He throws stuff and stomps around like he hates his job. He went to the bathroom and on his way there he cranked up the music. He's a total weirdo. 

Hey owners...here's a suggestion...get rid of him...he's bad for business. He's got a bad vibe about him. Good drinks but he is SO unpleasant that if I see him there, I won't get drinks. I'm not paying the premium for these drinks to be treated like shit. Sorry, not sorry.
author: Stance L.

description: I just noticed that the noise level is listed as "average," which is not my experience here. It's been at least 6+ months since I've been to the Alchemist and while I think it is a cool spot I've found the noise level to be consistently high, making it difficult to hold conversations at times.
author: Cliff B.

description:
If you want a laid back yet intimate lounge with ample space and ridiculously good drinks, you'll really enjoy yourself here.  The innovative cocktail menu enables you to be adventurous and try drinks you normally wouldn't order.  I'm not a a big bourbon fan but the Papaya Inn (I may have butchered the name) which was their cocktail of the week was absolutely delicious.  

Try to arrive before 8pm for HH if you want to save a few dollars on drinks (cocktails are $8 vs. $12) and grab a seat on one of the comfy couches.
author: Michele L.

description:
Super cool and chill space. Located conveniently near public transit and ATT Park, so overall very accessible! 

It's right above Woodbury!
author: Samantha C.

description: Came here before a Giants game, and it was perfect for pre-game drinks. It wasn't super packed at all - my friends and I got a table just fine. I was trying to decide between two diff specialty cocktails, and told the bartender what I was feeling and he made the perfect selection for me. Loved the vibe and decor - reminded me of Portland, Or. It was kinda hard to find given that there's no really noticeable sign and it was upstairs. Definitely will be back!
author: Tiffany T.

description: I really appreciate the owner taking the time to reach out and feel like he is trying to make changes.  The server who initially helped me had been very on top of it all.  It was just the bartender in the middle with serious attitude and was incredibly rude to customers.  I would consider coming back
author: Amanda K.

description:
An experience is what I would call this place. Drive up to its location and you would never know it is the happening place it is. A friend of ours recommended we try the old fashioneds. My husband really liked them. It was too strong for my taste so they "lightened" it up for me. 

The atmosphere is nice with pub tables, couches and chairs a great place to go with friends or a loved one. Our only complaint was it was hard to get service. We were there at 8:30 pm on a Saturday.
author: Tracy B.

description:
Multiple drinks that fancy the whiskey drinker. They are made with lots of care and so take a few minutes.

Love the interior and the shadow puppet shows. There is no words to them so it brings me back to the old school booths at fairs I have seen abroad like in Istanbul. 

It does get loud and crowded, but it is a great stop off before dinner.
author: Elaine L.

description:
Atmosphere of the bar is great! 

I am old fashioned. And by that, I mean I was born in the Victorian Era-or at least from a Tim Burton film/Edgar Allan Poe pages. The place is dark and mysterious and it's just really great. Definitely my kind of scene. 

The drinks have a lot of character. It does take a while to make but I swear it's worth the wait if you're patient enough! 


The bartenders are all pretty nice and very attentive. 
Cocktails are all $12 tho. Kind of pricey, but they all taste amazing. 

I really like the furniture they have set up around the lounge. They also play these silent short films on the walls. 

The bathrooms are also big, CLEAN and stocked which is important to me because I am a germaphobe and its always gross to have to stand in a small cramp space just to use the toilet/or wash your hands. 

I don't know what other bars are out there in SF with the same kind of ambience/theme, but I really love the whole steampunk vibe to the place. I hope there's more for me to check out!
author: Anna M.

description: Not a good first experience, we did a leaving party for a couple of colleagues because it was close to work and almost everyone was grossly overcharged for cards on tab. A couple people had their personal items pinched (my phone was taken at the bar from under my hand right and suspiciously the last people there were myself and a friend left with the staff). All around an upsetting night.
author: Celine O.

description:
Sometimes I come here and can't decide between several drinks, other times the shuffleboard is the only thing that interests me.  

I revisited recently and they had 2 different mezcal-based cocktails and at least 2 different whiskey/bourbon/rye/scotch-based cocktails, so I was quite pleased.  One of the drinks I had was the 1919 - rye, dark rum, punt e mes, benedictine, mole bitters.  A tad sweet for my taste because of the punt e mes, but still very enjoyable.  My friend got a Brooklyn and it was also very well made.  None of the drinks were as unique as the Room with a Vieux or the Stop Fenneling Me I had when they first opened, but they were still all good, stiff drinks.

3 weeks later: I guess they added more summery drinks to their specialty cocktail menu which left it  devoid of dark, complex, and spirituous concoctions.  Time to default to an Old Fashioned.
author: Beatrice W.

description:
BFF's B-Day celebration drinkys & he chose Alchemist Bar & Lounge

As Sis & I walk up, the bouncer cards us & actually gives Sis a hard time b/c he couldn't see her birth year through the plastic window in her wallet.....really??  We've each been 21+ for longer than we care to remember ( or admit )....I mean, we're not even close & you're *really* being such a stickler that she take her license out of the wallet?

Anyways, after barely getting past Checkpoint Charlie, we go upstairs to find the loudest bar we've been to in some time.  The person next to me is screaming at top volume yet I can barely hear her

I did like the comfy couches & chairs they have scattered all over the bar area - makes it seem like you're sitting in someone's living room.  Also liked the videos they had projecting on various walls - films of animated shorts & silent films - very cool

Drinks were way expensive & *completely* watered down - I don't like paying $11 for something that resembles flavored water - no punch, no kick... we're talking barely any flavor whatsoever

I had chosen the "Somethin' With Vodka".  It was supposed to have vodka, elderflower liqueur, lavender something & gingerbeer.....all I tasted was water

Sis however thought her glass of Chardonnay was delightful - nice & buttery

The B-Day Boy was drinking scotch all evening.....so by sheer volume, he was feeling no pain but those drinks had the same watered-down taste as mine ( I tried it for myself )

So for being godawful loud & topping it w/ watered down drinks, Methinks Not.....but for offering a cool ambiance & hosting all the loud fraternity-boys' clubs, am rounding up to a Meh, Seen Better rating......this isn't a place I'd choose
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Comfortable atmosphere, refreshing drink selection, and attentive staff make this a go to spot for happy hour and get togethers with friends and coworkers. Best part - very little to no douchebaggery - an affliction all too many SF bars have in abundance.

Call ahead and reserve space for you and your friends of you have a good sized group (6+).
author: Matt B.

description:
This is the first bar I've ever visited in San Francisco, but I expected a little more from a prohibition themed place. I loved the beaker glasses used for drinks, and the drinks themselves were really good! I had a "Something with Vodka" which consisted of vodka, elderflower liqueur, lime, thyme syrup, and ginger beer. Their other cocktail creations were pretty tasty (and strong) too. My only complaint is the slow bartenders.

I came here on a Friday night, and it surprisingly was not crowded at all. There was plenty of space to either sit at the bar or chill around the room. The vibe was alright, nothing too upbeat or exciting. When I first walked in, it took me awhile to realize that Alchemist was going for a prohibition feel. Overall it's a cool place to just relax, have some good drinks, and hang out.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
At first pass by you'd miss it.  Once you've doubled back and finally found the guy outside waiting to check your ID you think you've found the right spot.  Head upstairs and you'll know you've found the right spot.

Exposed brick walls line this hidden gem or great mixed drinks and noir movies playing on the walls.

Tip:  Try the Tater-tots.  You wont regret it.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Came here for drinks after on a Tuesday night with some friends.  It was nicely decorated for Halloween and as we walked up the stairs, it had a good Haunted house feel.  Once up top, you find a spacious lounge area with plenty of seating and a lofted area with more seating.  In the back there is a large bar that offers more seating.  There is also a shuffle board table in the back to the side.  A very welcoming atmosphere, although it was fairly empty being Tuesday night.

As for the drinks, I had the B.A. Baracus to continue my scotch binge that night, and because it was named after a fictional American Legend.  Just like its name sake, it packed a strong punch, but was delightful to the taste pallet.  Also had a taste of the Beez Nuts, which was decent.  

The specialty drinks are around $11 each, pricey but typical for SF.  I would definitely come back to drink and hangout more cause I think they make some of the better drinks in SF. I pity the fool who doesn't agree.
author: Veasna H.

description: Devent little upstairs spot near the ballpark. Good prices on beers, have you mixed drinks. Seems like a spot for regulars but appealing to all comers - beware of the neighborhood, gets kind of desolate after midnight.
author: Evan L.

description:
Alchemist is an intriguing new bar in an area that's not too famous for its bar scene. I came here on a typical Friday night with some friends after Off the Grid to see if this place really matches with all the fantastic reviews.

Cocktail menu is nice and short with a good variety of unheard of creations. Pretty standard prices. The drinks are nicely crafted, but not out of this world. I had a Campfire Fizz, a fascinating blend of  mezcal, cherry herring, lemon, simple syrup, egg and IPA. You often see beer in cocktails, but not IPAs. However, it turned out giving the drink a nice bitter taste. I tried several others that my friends ordered and they were also decent, but nothing to rave about.

There's ample room to move around, so don't worry about being squished here. Some areas do get cramped but there's a large space by the windows and upstairs if you want to keep to your bubble. Not too much room to sit down with your friends. Big thumbs up for the shuffleboard table, though! 

One thing that bothers me about this place is it seems to have an identity crisis. The bartenders are quite slow and like to take their time chatting up with the customers when there's people waiting for drinks. It tries to come off as an underground prohibition-style bar, but it's just not working with the quality of drinks and decor. It's decorated as more of an art studio than a bar with its wide open spaces. 

Good drinks, awesome shuffleboard table, but the overall concept needs some work.
author: Dmitriy S.

description:
This is a pretty nice lounge. It's actually upstairs, which I was not expecting, but walking into the main entrance was nice and the door man was friendly. The place is pretty big and I'm assuming they have dancing going on in the evening time. They have some very interesting cocktails. I ended up ordering the B.A. Baracus (scotch, lemon, ginger & habanero syrup, cider). It was pretty good, though I find it interesting that this drink has cider in it when we were told by one of the bartenders that they don't carry cider. Hmm. 

When I first got there, there weren't too many people there and we were able to get a seat at the bar. After we got our drinks, more people showed up and it seemed like some of them had to wait awhile to get their drinks ordered. I think it may be because the bar itself is on the small side or maybe it was because there were only 2 bartenders. I'm not sure. Also, if you are hungry, they have a small appetizer menu from the place next door.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
What I love about writing 5 star reviews is I can gloat and be seemingly "nice" as opposed to writing 1 star reviews where I get to rant like a neurotic, PMSing implacable beezie. Better Yelp then taking it out on Mr. NSS, I suppose. =/

And then comes 3 star reviews... mundane and mediocre 3 star reviews; nothing to gloat or rant about aka one boring ass review.

This is how I felt about Alchemist Bar & Lounge; mundane, mediocre, and boring. Previously, 3rd Degree Lounge (http://www.yelp.com/biz/3rd-degree-lounge-san-francisco), Alchemist is just another speakeasy type bar above Roots restaurant serving artisanal cocktails ($11). They have nonalcoholic drinks ($6) available as well. My friend tried one of their too sweet cocktails (Something with Vokkah) so I stuck with shots the entire night. 

Happy hour is 4 pm - 8 pm with $5 bubbly, $2 off wine and $1 off bottled beer.

While the concept is similar to Local Edition, Alchemist is absolutely NO Local Edition nor any members of the Bourbon & Branch family as some people have made comparisons to (it's about 1/3 the size with a meh crowd). My Local Edition review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/local-edition-san-francisco#hrid:YxyqAF7eq2lUHsl1odWlSg. 

I came here on a Saturday night at 10:30 pm  and I was ready to leave as soon as I walked in. Not that it was horrible but it just wasn't my scene. It felt like a boring corporate happy hour sans your power tripping douchebag boss. It's the weekend people, liven up!

PROS
*No cover.
*No dress code (people dress up though).
*Super friendly doorman (this otherwise would have been a 2 star review). 
*Snazzy speakeasy theme with exposed red brick walls, wooden beams and vintage furnishings. Kinda played out but it was an improvement over 3rd Degree Lounge. 

CONS
*NO eye-candy. Something beyond their control but I don't want to have to drink till he or she is cute.
*No music (at least I couldn't hear any); just an extremely loud box of chatter.
*Bartenders were snotty and seemed like they were doing us a favor when ordering.
*Limited alcohol selection.
*Just ordering a drink here takes a while and getting an artisanal cocktail even longer so come with a lot of patience.
*Bar stools (and people sitting in them) BLOCKED the entire bar area making a drink even harder and longer to get in hand. Every bar/lounge I've been to clear the stools after 10 pm so why can't Alchemist do the same?
*Limited seating area.

Pro Tip: IF you're a beer drinker or shots person, you're better off rolling in a keg or refilling your flask from the nearby liquor store. It will be much faster. Just saying...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Cute lil speak easy spot.  Film projected on the brick wall. Hamd crafted drinks. Open space. Vintage furniture and good upbeat music. Great bar to come hang out with friends. Enjoy!
author: Wynn N.

description:
Came here for a company party and the bartender was so rude! Ordered my first drink of the night- El Diablo which had tequila, lime, ginger beer, and something else. While she started making the drink I said "that doesn't come with salt or anything does it?" (I hate salt and garnishes on my drink). Sour bartender: "It's not a margarita, OK?" Ooookkaaayyyyy, and you're not a bartender you're a "mixologist," right? Other people complained how rude this bartender was so I'm not alone. With all the competition in SOMA it would be wise not to cop a 'tude with your customers. 

For the rest of the night I ordered from the nice cocktail waitress (blonde), and she took care of our group. Guy at the door was really nice too. The decor was neat and it got pretty crowded for the happy hour, even on a Wednesday. Our group usually heads to Utah, Southside, or 21st after work, and we'll probably stick to those 3.
author: Alyssa J.

description: David is the friendliest door man in SF - all around, fantastic venue with great bartenders and pretty decent bar food
author: George G.

description: Will took care of my work party. Everyone was really happy with their drinks, offering each person a taste. He absolutely blew my socks off with The Moon Rabbit. I had the Juan Solo first and it was fantastic but the Rabbit is where it's at. Tastes like a Chile Mango candy like I got as a child from mi abuela.... those from a Latin back ground know what I'm taking about. Atmosphere was sexy and fun. We will be returning!
author: Ry B.

description:
Finally there's something to do after a Giants game that isn't owned by Peter Osborne (though I think he's a lovely man and I've spent plenty of time at Pete's, Pedros, and Momo's). There's been a bit of a bar monopoly near AT&T Park, and with the advent of Alchemist, you have an option between continuing the shots/beer/well drink trend you've set inside the ballpark, or enjoying haute couture libations here at SOMA's newest mixology destination.

It's a huge space with more than enough room for the entire National League to kick up their feet, and I like their sense of humor. With drink names like Beez Nuts, Shrub Down, and Room with a Vieux, it's enough to get a giggle and $15 out of me. Plus, a great guy by the name of Kinson (Gitane) is part of the operation, so you know it's in good hands.

Early adopters, get in first and watch this acorn grow into a wild oak.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
If you're a fan of Local Edition and Rickhouse cocktails but hate the crazy crowds, then you'll like sipping your cocktails here in peace during happy hour. 

My personal favorite is the Beez Nuts - gin,chamomile, lemon, and honey. Let's just call it the nectar of god! AMAZING! I'm usually not a fan of gin, but there's not a trace of that icky juniper aftertaste with this drink.   

Bonus: There is a free shuffleboard table here!
author: Catherine C.

description:
3.5 stars

Came here for a couple of pre-Valentine's dinner drinks with my bf because it was nearby the restaurant. We saw that they were having a Pajama party for vday so I was kind of reluctant to go in, but no one was really participating "yet", the bouncer said. He was nice and funny. They also had drink specials that day though ($1 off cocktails and beer, $2 off wine). I wasn't too sure if this was for happy hour or Valentine's day since we were each given a ticket for it. 

The bar itself is upstairs in a cozy, dimly lit space with a bunch of couches and smelled of popcorn. I was confused until I saw their mini popcorn machine and large can of caramel and cheese popcorn. That was pretty cool and it was free! They also play black and white movies on the wall. We didn't want to spoil our appetite so we just headed over to the bar. It took the bartenders a while to acknowledge us, which was a little annoying. When they finally did, I ordered the Death in a Rose Garden cocktail ($11). The price seemed kind of steep especially since it came in a small gimlet, but it was strong! It also tasted too much like bitters to me. I don't recommend this drink unless maybe you're already drunk and at that point where you will drink anything set in front of you. Maybe their other drinks are better-tasting.

Overall, this is a pretty cool bar to chill at if you're in the area, but I think the bartenders should be a little more attentive and drinks are a little pricey especially since it was supposed to be happy hour.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Great place, helpful bartenders.  But the crowd here is meh - through no fault of the bar itself, of course.

The owners here apparently really care about making this place a success.  When I left a tip on Yelp they actually responded with a note.  Big bonus points in my book.  I wish you luck...maybe think about how to attract a more upscale clientele.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I have been waiting 6 months for Alchemist to open, I finally got to enjoy it more than once this week. And it was totally worth the wait. It's definitely going to become the newest hot spot in SF. Amazing cocktails (BA Barachus, Monkey Gland, Campfire Fizz were my favorites), totally unique decor with old black and white movies projected on the walls. The space itself is huge and was at maximum capacity causing a line at the door.  On that note I'm curious if Shawn C. was confused and at a different bar than the rest of us. It does take time to get a cocktail but 3 bartenders for what seemed like 200 people... have some patience people! 
One more thing,  HH goes til 8!
author: stephani p.

description: Even if I were 5-10 years younger (albeit 10 years younger means non-drinking age), I still don't think I'd dig this vibe. The music randomly goes up with Top 40 hits that "speak to" the bartenders, and it's kind of dead in here for a Saturday night, even with The Weeknd's new single blaring. This is a bar that tourists might be into, but as a native San Franciscan, it's a poor man's Southside Spirit House, except it's almost exactly on-par in prices. The decor and drinks just aren't as strong, and they have no food. The bartenders are chill, but the drinks are weak, and while you'd think this would be a place gamers might frequent, it really isn't. I really would take the non-liquor, but quieter atmosphere of 21st Amendment over this any day. At least that place has tvs and people who talk to each other instead of just looking like sulking, brooding bodies. Oh, there is a shuffleboard.
author: Danny C.

description:
According to Foursquare The Alchemist Bar has been open since September. I stopped here with some friends on NYE since they weren't charging a cover and I like Local Edition which is what many have compared it to in reviews.

They are pretty swanky and they even had a photobooth here for the occasion.

Drinks are also pretty strong I might add. Prices were about $8 and up. I ended up getting the Bee'z Nuts which had honey, ginger and some other deliciousness in it. There was a version of High Life that was available for the evening as well.

The lounges were all reserved for the evening but this is definitely a good event space. There's also shuffle board so if you like do activities at bars, I suggest you check this place out. I didn't have much trouble finding it. It's near the ball park.
author: Amy J.

description:
Full disclosure I'm new to the city and this was my first night out. Alchemist was the second bar of the evening but my favorite. The decor and architecture of the building is really nice. The website said steampunk which can get overly theme but it was very urban industrial with just a touch of whimsy to keep it well out of Disney territory; exposed brick, wood beams, comfy leather couches arranged in different seating areas. For the lounge feel of the atmosphere I was surprised the music was so loud, dance club loud (10 to midnight), it seemed out of place since most people were talking and had to shout over it. 

The drinks were amazing. I had the "and something with vodka" nice clean drink, a little herbaceous with thyme, and a subtle sweet finish. I would defiantly have it again. My friend had the "bitter forest", I don't usually drink gin, but this was also really good. Most importantly the staff was friendly, it was easy to get to the bar for a drink, the bartender acknowledged us right away, took our orders and was nice enough to pour us waters with our drinks.
author: Rachel G.

description:
So glad to see this place is finally open for good after all the drama with the guy who owns Momo's and a bunch of other bars on the Embarcadero. (He basically didn't want anyone else moving into the neighborhood and stealing his business, so the guys here couldn't get a liquor license for the longest time) 

I was lucky enough to experience Alchemist during their earlier days when they were only able to be open one night at a time. And even a few months ago I could already tell there was something magical about this place. The decor is amazing, there's a speakeasy vibe to the venue that makes you feel like you've been teleported back in time. There's a few seating areas but this is mostly a place where you grab a drink at the bar and then stand and mingle. The bartenders make amazing cocktails *pinkys up* when you drink because they're fancy. Can't wait to come back before/after a Giants game since they're so close to the ballpark!
author: Sarah L.

description:
Great lounge with a lot of space, friendly staff, and good drinks.

If you're coming here with a large party, you should book out a lounge. Otherwise the actual bar area is a bit cramped. But the 8 person lounge really fits more like 12 people seated, and there's a lot of standing space.

Lounge reservations can only be done online, don't bother calling it. It will just tell you go online.

Overall the drinks were very good (with some duds but only a few!)

The B.A. Baracus actually has a bit of kick to it! Pretty tasty as well.

Smoking with the Devil sounds like it would be hot, but it's not. But still good.

I had a lot of other drinks, and they are all good except for one which I don't remember. Oh well.

The lounge makes things much better. It's very comfortable and spacious.
The space is fairly loud, but it's nice and has a good atmosphere. Servers are friendly and actually fairly fast for it being so crowded.
author: Michael W.

description: This is an awesome bar on weekdays when it's not so crowded. On weekends it can get too crowded to the point where it's impossible to get from where you're standing to the bar to order a drink.
author: Derrick W.

description: Great New Years party in Sf! We had a full service bar that actually gave you service. A good DJ and a fun photo booth. The place wasn't pretentious and the staff were friendly and attentive. During the countdown they offered everyone champs to toast. Overall great first SF New Years experience!
author: Ariana R.

description: Good vibe, plenty of patrons on a Wednesday night.  But man, the cocktails. They were good.  Service was a bit slow, but everything was delivered with friendliness and a smile.  A mix of business and hipster. I'd come back... For the cocktails.
author: Angela K.

description: Love the ambiance and the cocktails here. It's connected to Woodbury bar , I find that very convenient. I go here a lot, great neighborhood gem.
author: C A.

description:
I came here with my coworkers last Thursday for Happy Hour with my coworkers. Warning now: It opens at 5 PM, so don't try to go earlier.

I love the decor. It was very old school speakeasy style with a lot of vintage things all around with the brick walls.

Beer selection was limited. I had the Pilsneur Urquell all evening, and it was $1 off during happy hour. Another thing that irked me was that a lot of people were sitting around the bar, so it was difficult to even walk up to the bar to grab a drink..

Seating wasn't much though. I think two sections were already reserved for Levi's and Adobe, so my company and I were sitting in this little corner chatting with one another. The music got really really really loud at one point, so I couldn't even really hear what they were talking about.

I think this place definitely has potential, just tiny little fixes here and there.
author: Joanne W.

description:
Hit this place up the weekend before Halloween on a Saturday night. It's a pretty chill bar and it looked like the late 20's early 30's crowd.

Some people were dressed up, some where not, but overall a fun place. They had Halloween drink specials and decorations throughout. 

No cover.

They had music in the background, but no one was dancing. We ended up leaving for a place with a dance floor because what's a night's a night out with letting loose?
author: Leana L.

description:
Very cool and stylish decor. Drinks were made with skill and speed. Bartender was friendly enough as it was quite busy. Good potential here.
 Why the two stars? 70s bullshit dance music played at earsplitting volume! No one was dancing! NO ONE! Everyone was trying to socialize but had to yell. If you look at the person you are trying to listen to, enjoy the droplets of spit in your eye. 
 My friends assured me that we were meeting them at a cool lounge, not a dance club. They know I hate those places.
 Loud as hell and hot as balls should be the name of this place. Never going back. Plenty of good bars in the city that don't play shitty music at the highest setting. Kind of sad because the place looks really cool. Can't really describe the look other than to say it would have made sense to hear Sisters of Mercy, DM or NIN being played. Not blared mind you, just played at a normal bar volume.
 
UPDATE: MARCH 3 2015 Phil C from Alchemist messaged me and was quite apologetic about my experience.
He assured me that blaring music is not something that is supposed to happen there nor is 70 music normally played. Because the music being so loud was my only issue with the business I am adding two more stars and trusting that one could have conversations there after the issue was resolved.  Its a very stylish and properly lighted space (not too bright)  with good drinks. Therefore, I will return this weekend and give it another try. If I can talk to people without the need to yell, the four stars will remain intact.
 Thanks Phil. 
 Steve.
author: Steve M.

description:
Wow, apparently this place has been open for a few months already. I saw it on a blog and decided to come with a friend. I was looking for signage, but didn't see any; I had to look at the numbers on the buildings nearby to guide me and I saw an A-Board outside as well. 

+They were limiting the number of people inside - yes! I can't stand bumping against other people and squeezing through people to get to the bar. I'm small, so I usually have to get a friend to push through to order for me. No problems for me and my friends when we were here last night though :)

+Limited menu with interesting cocktails - I liked the Beez Nuts. We were here during happy hour, so my friends grabbed some bubbly for $5. Other happy hour items: $1 off bottle beer, $2 off wine

+ Interior decor - open space, a couple small counters located by pillars, light projects of pictures/quotes. I liked the look and feel!

I'll definitely come back after work on Fridays with friends again to grab some drinks and chill.
author: Katherine S.

description:
+ decor is awesome (who doesn't love an antique typewriter in the entrance hall)
+ nicely renovated - love the wood everywhere
+ spacious interior
+ quick service
+ reasonable prices
- cocktails tend to be on the dry/sour side (not my preference)
author: Sherry L.

description: After a rough experience outside Pier 70, was looking for something good on Yelp, this place definitely improved my night. It has a good lounge crowd was mostly locals, the vibe and music (mostly older tasteful hip/hop) was cool. The food downstairs stars at the connected bar was pretty tasty bar fare. Staff and security was friendly and approachable, definitely worth a visit!
author: Charles M.

description:
Super cute venue with crafty and clever-named drinks!!!

A friend celebrated her 29th birthday here recently. There is a cute private booth area upstairs you can reserve without a fee.  You get unlimited "water" bottle service on ice, but you must order drinks at the bar or with the server.  Because they had their Christmas decorations and lights up, the place was even cuter.

The place looks like there could be a dance floor, but the crowd was more of a mingling and socializing nature.  The music kept going back and forth between pop/upbeat and slow/R&B, which was a little confusing.

Drink to try: Something with Vodka
author: Elisha Y.

description: A group of friends get together once a month at a location near to the station for happy hour. It was so loud, we had to shout at one another, the music was set for a late weekend night not a happy hour level. I also think the bar tenders were struggling with the speed of service. Craft cocktails take time to make, so when the first bar tender is working on specialty drink and the second is talking the entire time to people, that I assume are friends, it was frustrating to have to wait. He didn't even try to make eye contact with me or pause the conversation to help his peer. I hope they don't share tips because one guy definitely did way more work than the other~
author: Sarah S.

description: perfect  lounge. Not too busy and not too empty, just perfect.
author: Kayla A.

description: Cute lil speak easy spot.  Film projected on the brick wall. Hand crafted drinks. Open space. Vintage furniture and good upbeat music. Great bar to come hang out with friends. Enjoy! And go to the Woodbury next door, a sister spot, and really cool too.
author: Amy L.

description:
Good cocktail bar. The layout's a bit weird, with a ton of open space, but not a lot of seating. 

I've gone a few times because the drinks are good, but something's a bit weird to me about the space.
author: Dimple B.

description:
3.5
I really like the feel and atmosphere of this place. The old fashion movies projected onto the brick walls really gives this place a 1920s feeling. Great place to hangout and grab a drink especially on game day because of it's close proximity to AT&T park. 

Only thing I didn't like about this place is that the beer isn't on tap. Not a big deal although I probably would have tried a cocktail if I knew beforehand.
author: Edward W.

description:
If it's date night and you're all caught up in the love zone, this is the spot you want to be at to have an intimate time to talk and spit some game to your date. The lighting and ambiance is perfect. No ratchet music and no TVs are on to distract you from your cupcaking.

If you're just trying to chill and have a kick back with the crew, get down to the bar next door downstairs bc that's where they have TVs with sports on and video games and awesome music.

Aside from all that, Alchemist is a very nice craft bar to chill. They have great drinks and a really helpful friendly staff to help you figure out what drink you are in the mood for!
author: Joe N.

description: If it weren't for the bouncer named Carl (apologies if he wasn't a bouncer). We were getting heckled by some giants fans at the bar on the first floor. He let us know that we would feel comfortable going to the alchemist, because there wasn't the sports bar feel at this place. Needless to say, I may have found my favorite lounge so far. The place has a cool atmosphere and the drinks are expertly made. Thank you Carl, for taking care of your customers, when you didn't need to.
author: Ryan S.

description: Free street fighter/ snes and Atari makes this the best bar I've ever been to. The drink menu is priced accordingly. Where else can you go to get a shot of tequila and beer for $10. The fries and tots (perfectly crunchy) were so good that I had to try something else. I ended up ordering a burger which was similar to umami burger. Downstairs plays mostly hip hop while upstairs is more packed but plays non hip hop. I would recommend this bar to everyone.
author: Ryan G.

description: bar tender sucks , the guy in the ponny tail is rude. Ive never had to work so hard to spend my money at a bar.
author: Khaled S.

description:
The way that this place is laid out makes it super loud all the time. The mood is very "calm" and "dark" but you don't really get that vibe because of the noise. 

Bartenders seem a bit snooty, but maybe because they get so busy. The drinks are a bit on the expensive side - this isn't a dive where you get a shot of Jamie and a can of Bud. 

Clientele is VERY male. Not surprising for soma. Lots of younger tech folks, but overcrowded with giants fans on game days even though it's really not that type of bar. Just crowds and crowds. Seriously. The noise is crazy in this bar for some reason more so than others. 

Overall, it's my least favorite place to go around this area between victory, polo, 25 lusk and so forth.
author: Julie K.

description: This is one of the neatest bars I have been to since coming to SF! Located upstairs, there is a menu for Happy Hour, as well as a decent drink selection (non-happy hour cocktails around $10). There are beautiful projections on the walls of the bar, with ambient seating around the place. Has an open feel while also being a relatively small bar, was not crowded at all when I visited!
author: Kuhray V.

description:
I adore the idea of stepping into a bar and feeling teleported to another era or region.  Alchemist Bar SCREAMS 19th century industrial revolution mixed with a speakeasy feel.

Walking in, I hear a "vintage" record player playing music and low lighting to set the mood.  The bar is upstairs and it's a brick walled room with tons of vintage leather couches and wooden stools.  On the walls they play black and white movies through a projector.

Alchemist is great if you're looking for a low-key and casual place to meet some friends for some delicious mixologist-made drinks.  They have a happy hour and also a bar menu if you're looking for some light bites.

I can't speak on any of the food or service because I was just here to be a DD.. But I know that I'll definitely be back!
author: Michelle W.

description:
Brick walls, exposed ceiling, a black and white film playing on one wall, a steam-punk clip looping above the liquor shelves, a shuffleboard table against another, old school leather couches to lounge on, interesting items on display throughout the lounge. Need I say, different? I like! I'm not one for clubs and I don't really drink as I'm typically the DD. Here you can really relax and chat with people without being super overwhelmed and unable to breathe.

Drinks I've tried
B.A. Baracus: Scotch, Lemon, Ginger & Habanero Syrup, Hard Cider
Somethin' With Vokahh: Vodka, Elderflower Liqueur, Lime, Thyme Syrup, Ginger Beer
Sober Til The End of Thyme: Thyme Syrup, Lime, Ginger Beer, Tonic

I love ginger so I love how several drinks here feature it. In addition, not many lounges have appealing non-alcoholic drinks that aren't from a can/bottle. Bonus points! Plus, you can find a lot of unique drinks here if you like to venture out and try.

Friendly staff. Fairly chill crowd. Cool ambiance. :)
author: Kitty K.

description:
Death in a rose garden. 
Smoking w the devil. 

And be an old fogie couple like us and show up when it opens. Tables galore.
author: Antara B.

description:
Dark and Loud and Snooty. I'd quicker visit a sensory deprivation chamber or a goth club than go back to this place again. 

Tasty drinks (for the price of a nice meal) though!
author: Janet K.

description:
Alchemist is a cool spot to hang out after work and catch up with friends/colleagues. The vibe of the place is dimly lit, loud music, and fun people making it a very cozy setting despite the noise. The place reminds me of Local Edition with the mixed cocktail menu but with cooler names. I had the "Somethin' With Vokahh" and it was great! 

There is an upstairs area but I didn't go check it out. There is some sort of game table in the back but didn't get too close to check it out. One thing to keep in mind is that the place is small so prepare to get cozy with the other patrons! Seriously though, at times it was difficult to maneuver around the crowd. 

One thing I didn't like was the bar setup allowing patrons to sit at the bar. This was a huge hindrance on a busy night for those who wanted to get the bartenders attention for drinks. People please - if you already have your drink let others through instead of huddling with your group right in front of the bar. This way we can all enjoy what Alchemist has to offer :)

Regardless, I would definitely consider this place for meeting up with friends and possible holding a private event here. 

Plus, the lounge is easily walkable from the Caltrain. Being a South Bay gal, I am always on the lookout for places to hang out within distance of the train station.

Can't wait to come back and try some of the other cocktails!
author: Jessica S.

description: This place is ok. I don't really consider it a speak easy since it's  easy to find. Note that the parking meters run until 10pm in front of this place. Space is decent, but does get super crowded. The bar is kind of small, so try to grab a seat at the bar if you can, or else you'll never be able to get a drink. Even if you're sitting at the bar, the bartenders aren't very attentive, probably because it's super busy. The best drink here was the smoking with the devil. Everyone I was with agreed that the drinks are good, but there's no alcohol in it. Had like 3 drinks, didn't even get a buzz. Good place if you have a party, but alcohol is weak here. Also note, this place can be shut down for private events. Better to call before heading there.
author: Lisa T.

description:
The first time I tried their drinks at Off the Grid, I thought the were pretty awesome, but this time around, all of the cocktails were pretty disappointing, and we ended up getting charged for the bartender's mistakes on our order.   

The upstairs area here is kind of stuffy, and I prefer the downstairs bar much more.  The Omen tasted like a cream soda, but not in a great way, and my Bitter Forest wasn't exactly bitter (it was pretty fruity).

Maybe taking mixology classes and having gone to some other craft cocktail focused places in the city have raised my bar since the last time I tried their drinks..
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Nice decor but it is a little dark. Though, I guess that's the point. It's a speakeasy with craft cocktails that seem a little light. Lot of sports coats walking around so I guess this is where the cool kids hang out.

Sadly though, no mule. Or no real mule. 

They do have drink specials though.
author: Victor C.

description: Very cool bar/lounge that's in a lofty SOMA building and reminds me of Edison in Los Angeles. Chill vibe with leather armchairs, edison bulb lighting, and black & white film projecting on the walls. Most people were talking while sitting or standing; this is not a dance club. Great space to mingle and have a good night. Drinks were also very well made and paid a lot of attention to detail. Would come back again!
author: Audrey L.

description: Overall a cool bar with a hipsterish ambiance.  Drinks are reasonably priced and the bartenders are speedy for the most part. I haven't had a chance to try the food, so I'll make sure to edit my review for that.  All in all a great place to hang out with friends.
author: Jack S.

description:
What a fun gem by the ballpark. The Alchemist Bar has a hint of a speakeasy feel where you don't see the bar from the street because it's above. 

When we came, the bouncer was very very friendly and made sure we were in the right spot. Of course, booze is always our spot. My sis and I took a seat right at the bar. The drink menu was short with not a lot of variation to the different drinks. So, we did what any classy bartender would love  (I could only guess they like this): We told her to make us two tequila drinks that had spice and egg whites. Man, she blew us out of the park! The drinks were delish and the price was a reasonable $11 for custom cocktail. 

This place I am sure gets crazy when games are at the ballpark but if you can catch a quiet night, it's a great date spot or a classy cocktail lounge for a group of friends (4-5 people. 

The reason I didn't give it a five is because the wardrobe of the bartenders didn't match the bar scene. It was a very trendy bar and the bartenders were wearing something you would wear to a boxing gym...
author: Ezequiel R.

description: Ambiance great. Drinks are very expensive and terrible though, including wine! The other ratings are a bit misleading in my opinion.
author: Can B.

description: I visited this bar for a St. Patrick's day mixer, and while the look of the bar is excellent, the noise level made communicating very difficult. I'd give it 5 stars, if they'd turn the music down from 11. Drinks were nice, but a little too much ice, making the price a little harder to justify. Overall, a nice hipster-type bar. The silhouette movies on the wall were a nice touch for the atmosphere.
author: Ryan K.

description:
The Alchemist Bar & Lounge is a new spiffy bar located in San Francisco's SOMA neighborhood. The crowd consisted of nothing but young, hip & classy, perhaps a little bit of trendy as well. Swank decor, soothing ambiance, friendly bartenders & no cover....I loved everything about this spot! I came here on a Friday night w/ my girlfriends and was surprised to bump into more friends throughout the night. 

Fun Tip: The best drink on the menu is the 4th Regimen (rye whiskey, dolin rouge, dash of celery, orange & angosture bitters).
author: Viennelyn C.

description:
I really do like this place. I came here after a theater show and googling top 10 cocktail bars in SF. They live up to it. They have specialty cocktails Of which I ordered the Bitter Forrest and loved it. All the cocktails actually looked really tasty. 
The converted warehouse feel is great and good music was pumping. 
Quite a mixed crowd but everyone was polite enough to give each other space.
Definitely come back.
I did see a great happy hour on offer of 5-8pm Monday - Friday so will probably give  that a try too!
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
Okay, this place is pretty cool.  Came here on a Saturday night.  Seems like there would never be a line here, which made me a bit pessimistic, especially since looking in the front door, it's an empty hallway.

Upon entering, it was quite nice decor.  To your left, you will see random beakers & bottles of chemicals (ha, thus the name).  You will also see some strange antique record player.

You walk up a flight of stairs, and now you're in the bar!  It's quite warm up there, which is perfect for winter.  There is plenty of walking space, and tons of couches.  The environment is overall very intimate.

I ordered a drink I've never tried before.  Let's just call it the "shrub drink."  I also ordered one for my sister and girlfriend.  It supposedly tasted like Smarties.  Yes, that candy that you received on Halloween as a kid and always tried to trade 5 of them for 1 Kit Kat Bar.

I think I just ordered the wrong drink for my liking.  The overall place was fantastic, and service was prompt.  I live locally here and will definitely be coming back soon.
author: Andrew H.

description: Great, comfortable atmosphere. Good cocktails. 'B.A. Baracus' is a must-try for scotch cocktails & spice lovers. The place had very few people on a tuesday night so I can't really comment on the service. We got what we asked for though. I would imagine this place would be great on the weekends.
author: A. Emre Ü.

description: Awesome space and creative drinks. Best time to go is for pre-dinner drinks in the area. Otherwise you are at the mercy of the infamous SF "there is no one up stairs, but we'll keep a line outside to make it seem we're cool" bar syndrome.
author: Carlo M.

description: Solid happy hour, it was annoying though they had blocked off all the couches for "reservation. I was there for 2 hours and no body actually came.
author: Tiff W.

description:
Meh, below average bar. 

Exposed brick, industrial lighting. Looks cool, but the high ceilings just provide a lot of echo for bar that is way too loud or how empty it is. 

No beers on tap. Only bottle and cans.

Didn't try any of the cocktails because honestly the drafty environment did not merit an $11 cocktail.
author: Martina S.

description:
I'm in love with this place : ) 
It was a bit confusing at first as there were no signs pointing to upstairs.  My gfs and I were here celebrating a friend's birthday. Loved the ambiance . We felt so in place. .. it was our kind of crowd.  Looking around the crowded living room , it seemed as if we could stay a conversation about anything in tech with anyone here.  As 3 engineers looking to mingle and exchange ideas we loved this place and would definitely go back : )
author: Nikki A.

description: Quaint, cute, & cozy. Was looking for a place for a place to take a few friends out for a drink & this place was perfect. Reasonably price & chill. Only downfall is you have to go to the bar and get drinks bc there's no waitress. Went on a Thursday & bar wasn't too busy so it was fine.
author: Kiely N.

description:
Cool space on the second floor of a SoMa loft, above another sister bar that looked like a more chill version of what I found upstairs.

Besides the space, first impression was "loud and dark." Music was pretty high volume, and not conducive to deep conversation. A lot of Michael Jackson now that I'm thinking of it... Unless you stand right under a light by the central bar, you'll need the light of your phone to see the cocktail menu.

Really creative and interesting cocktails.
author: Aki N.

description: As a first timer with no expectations, this place was pretty great. Not a typical bar in terms of their drink specials. Instead, they boast cocktails made with real ingredients like egg yolk (I kid you not, it's called Smoking with the Devil), vegetables and fruit. It's got a nice ambience too.
author: Jamie L.

description:
A nice cozy place on the second floor. 
cocktail is good
The only issue is the music is too loud, almost impossible to talk.
author: Stella C.

description: So, the Alchemist is a really fun bar with delicious cocktails, a nice array of seating, and in a super convenient spot. But my favorite part of the Alchemist is their bouncer! He is super friendly, does a great job, and everytime I go there we have a brief chat. It's great how having one awesome employee makes people love your business that much more.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday a week or two ago, and I highly doubt I will ever be going back. The idea is cool, but it was executed very poorly. It has a "speakeasy" feel, the entrance of the bar is just a room with some cute vintage decor+music, and there's a black curtain. Doorman greets you, checks how legal you are and sends you upstairs to a beautiful bar... but that is where the magic ends. 

There are a couple of mixologists, a bar that is surrounded by tourists, and  the seating area has tons of empty chairs. When we got there, they had run out of the $4 beer, so we had to get their $6 beer (it was shitty.) Cocktails were extremely overpriced ($11 for a drink that has too much non-alcoholic filler in it?) 

The music was pretty much the best of Michael Jackson, there is no beer on tap, and the people that were there were awful. We ended up leaving after about 20 minutes and heading to tempest, because bars with pool tables are a lot more fun.

If you're kind of pretentious and like to be "seen" in hip spots, then this is DEFINITELY the place for you.
author: T M.

description: Good drinks but a but inconsistent as we ordered two drinks that were the same and each bartender made it completely different. The atmosphere is very laid back, people enjoy the food there, and there are NO TVs to keep away the crowd by the stadium who searches for bars in the area to watch the games. I'm not a big fan of the seating as it is awkward and normally 2/3 of the clusters are full but the chairs are too big and are awkward to stand around. Not the best use of space.
author: Lily P.

description: This place is easy to find and it's in a loft on the second floor.  The drinks are pretty good (most cocktails are $11).  There are couches and the space is big (doesn't feel stuffy since it's a loft).  Good place to have a drink with friends.  The crowd is boring.
author: Chris L.

description:
With all these new bars opening up around SF, it's incredibly hard for me to keep track of where I need to visit. Luckily, when you have friends that live in the city, it makes being in the "know," a whole lot easier. This particular night, we were in the SoMa watching the Giants play. The game ends as expected, and thus we are left with the rest of the night to drink. Public House and all those spots are okay, but I really wanted to try out some new spots in the area. The Alchemist, was definitely new, and boy do I like this spot. If you're coming from AT&T, it literally is about a 5 minute walk. There really isn't a dress code here considering the fact that it's so close to the ballpark, but people still do dress nicer than your average pub.

Alchemist is a 2nd story bar right on 3rd street. If you're just walking up 3rd Street, you might actually miss it because there aren't any huge signs telling you to come in for a drink. Once you walk upstairs, you're transformed from the baseball filled SoMa, to a lounge/speakeasy of sorts. The theme is definitely somewhere around the 1920-1950s. From the music, the foreign movies playing in the background, and the sofa/lounge area, everything screams speakeasy. Luckily, unlike most speakeasies, there is plenty of room to both sit, and stand around. Even on a Friday night, I was able to move around easily, with plenty of room to spare. 

As far as drinks go, it's your straight up cocktail bar. Alchemist does have their own concoctions such as the Beez Nuts, but I always stick to the Manhattan when I venture to cocktail bars. Price-wise, they're around the usual price of $12-15, so that shouldn't shock you at all. Taste-wise, my Manhattan was pretty amazing. It was strong, just how I like it, and had the right ratios of each of the ingredients. I enjoyed my drink, and the ambiance so much, that I proceeded to have another.

With so many bars in San Francisco, sometimes you just want to drink in a chill spot where you can actually hear what people are saying, and have room to move around. Alchemist fulfills both of those requirements, and adds on great ambiance as well. This is a great place to grab some drinks with a few friends, and even better, grab drinks after the Giants win another game.
author: Michael W.

description:
I really really really like this place. I've been here for a New Year's Eve party, work happy hour event, long night of drinks with an old friend to catch up, someone's birthday,  and will be back next week for happy hour with a small group.

Alright, let's do this.

DRINKS: Tasty cocktails for $11. Not a long a menu, but the variety is good. And if you have a sense of humor, you'll enjoy the names. I've at least tasted everything and haven't hated any of it. That's a big deal. Two Words: Beez Nuts!!! Two More Words (if you're dragging your friend here and they hate cocktails): High Life!!! If you're coming for an event, expect to wait a minute. 

FOOD: They have it! Get the sweet potato tater tots. Perfect for when you accidentally get drunk---you probably will---because the cocktails are stiff and the bartenders have lead hands. There's some other stuff on the menu, but these are easy to shove in your mouth.

SPACE: Beautiful day light. Dark and moody in the evenings. Tall ceilings, sweet brick walls. Not overly stylized. Sweet projections to stare at when you need a break from talking.

STAFF: Door dudes are awesome (they've laughed at my lame banter). Staff is TCOB. Bar back brought me water as I was borderline faded and ready to melt into my chair on New Year's Eve.

MUSIC: Good throwbacks playing in the background (50's, not 80's-90's). Louis Prima & Kelly Smith on the 1s and 2s! Find myself singing along in the restroom.

SPEAKING OF RESTROOM: May not be important to you, but it is to me! This is my least favorite part of being here. But it's multi-stall, clean, and I haven't had to wait in a long-ass line so I can't take a star away for that.

SEMI-PRIVATE EVENTS: I don't know if I suck at searching (I'm pretty sure I don't because I'm obsessive and research the shit out of everything), but does anyone realize how difficult it is to reserve a space that can accommodate a group of 20 for happy hour and serves food without a ridiculous minimum?! It's hard. So if you find yourself organizing events, just go here. You're welcome.

HOW IT COMPARES: Since everyone compares this place to Local Edition, I'll share my thoughts. The layout is open like Local Edition, the drink menu is equally tasty, and I've even see one of the bartenders working at both bars, but it definitely doesn't have the same atmosphere. The atmosphere (on weeknights, happy hour into the late evening) reminds me more of Rye: laid back, pleasant, ready and willing to work with whatever your drinking mood is.

OVERALL: Come here if you're looking for an interesting space to enjoy a great cocktail menu. And if you're looking for a classic done right or something obscure, the bartender dudes I've ordered from are legit so they have you covered. Oh yeah, there's shuffle board! WTF?! It's like El Rio and (fine) Local Edition had a baby!
author: Phoebe G.

description:
New hot spot in SOMA, at least new to me. 
Bar tenders are cool without attitude which is appreciated. 
Very crowded but still enjoyable.
author: Kevin K.

description:
+1 = nice staff
+1 = we need more places like this in SOMA
+1 = interesting drinks
+1 = AWESOME style and decor
-1 = the drinks were a bit pricey for their quality (although I did choose a weird one); and they didn't have enough seats for our larger group (awkward)
author: Chris W.

description:
Our hero popped in on a weekday to Alchemist for a drink and was pleasantly surprised.  Their decor is trendy without being annoyingly hipster and the entry way was lined with various potions and ingredients made our hero feel like he was walking into Hogwarts or something.  The venue feels like a multi-level brick walled warehouse space with a lot of nice lounge furniture and a dimly lit vibe.  There's no DJ's, annoying music videos, or anything too distracting going on, so this spot is prime for just chilling out and chatting.

Drinks are fairly standard for downtown at around $11 a cocktail and $6-8 a beer.  Their Japanese infused tater tots were also pretty cool and tasted great fresh out of the kitchen.  The menus here aren't overwhelming and the bartender was very good with recommendations and took time hand crafting a great drink.  This is definitely a bar worth checking out in the SoMa area of SF if you're into just hanging out with a couple friends in a non-pretentious, comfortable environment.

PROS:
- Really large spacious venue.
- Good social vibe that's apt for hanging out or a date.
- Simple but diverse food and cocktail menu that hits the spot.

CONS:
- They don't seem to have any beers on draft.  Bottles only.
author: Albert W.

description:
This is my pre-game drink location of choice for the 2013 season.  Fortunately  this bar is more consistently pleasing than the Giants have been of late.  Sigh...

I had the most delightful interaction with the boucer/doorman the other day, he made me laugh.  He's charming and funny, he kicks the experience off well.  I really like the stripped down, speakeasy feel of the place, the second floor open floor plan/large window combo give it a nice vibe and I love that you don't feel trapped even when the place is crowded.

The cocktail menu is what keeps us coming back though.  My go-to is the 'Somethin With Vodkah', I love the combo of thyme with elderflower liqueur.  I had a horse named Mr. T when I was little, so I also love that they have a drink called B.A. Baracus, sadly I'm not a scotch drinker, but still, it makes me happy that it's there.  It is also great that they have a couple of inventive non-alcoholic cocktails on the menu, for those times when it's your turn to be the designated driver but you want something more exciting than water or a soda.

All in all, this place is a winner and is well worth a stop.
author: Renae H.

description:
was taken here by a lovely friend. venue had good decor and ambiance, and place was very chill. i like being able to have a conversation. might have been because it was an off night during a weekday, but i could see it being annoying if it gets crowded and you can't find seating.
would definitely come again.
author: Xander C.

description: Great bar with excellent drinks.  Also loved the speakeasy-esque decor.  I will definitely be back again.
author: Debbie L.

description:
Decent old fashioned, cool atmosphere, shuffle-board table, and good happy hour. Service was good too. I wouldn't come here from any other part of town, but a good cocktail lounge if you are nearby. My table loved the chicken wings; I didn't try them however. 

I work nearby, so I'll definitely be back!
author: Sneha P.

description:
I appreciated the seating areas available and thought it had an overall cool vibe and a great place for groups of friends.

However, attitude of the bartender deserved a 0. I understand the concept of a mixology bar, I mean it has become as ubiquitous as macaroons, speakeasies, love of corgis and TOMS. What is never in style however is being rude to customers. We asked for a drink -  no, it wasn't a vodka soda - and was flatly denied. "No." was all I heard and he went on to ignore us. I politely inquired why and after a few seconds of superior silence he said, "We don't carry that. You can choose another brand, or something...if you want..." 

I'm sorry if I offended your superior mixologist sensibilities but you could have just said, "no, we don't carry that actually, we specialize in _. However, I'd recommend the __ if you like that kind of spirit." I've been to enough of these bars to know that the attitude shouldn't come standard.
author: Audrey N.

description:
Because of its second-floor location behind a stairwell, and the lack of aggressive front-door advertising, Alchemist retains the vibe of a secret speakeasy - something only those "in the know" can access, which makes the reveal at the entrance on the second floor a fun experience for first-time guests. 

The brass-and-glass steampunk-themed decor is beautifully laid out. The staff is friendly and professional, and the drinks (fun concoctions of exotic mixes) are quite strong. 

A great place to hang with friends in the SOMA area and Alchemist draws a fun and gender-balanced crowd (for those of you out there who are single).
author: kai c.

description:
Really enjoyed the decor and vibe of this spot. Comfy couches, good music, polite servers, knowledgeable bartenders and delicious drinks. Can you ask for more?
Had what might have been the best Old Fashioned I've ever had. And for only $8. Tried a couple other specialty cocktails and was pleasantly surprised by the flavor on the pallet and scents hitting the nostrils. 
I would definitely come back to this spot
author: Tim B.

description:
Love the decor and atmosphere of this bar
Convenient location
Good drinks, slightly over priced though
Not overly crowded (brownie points in my book!)
Bartenders are friendly
I had some interesting champagne concoctions! I am not a fan of the bubbly unless its an occasion to celebrate - but these drinks kept me going for more
It's a lounge kinda setting with enough and comfortable seating space
author: Kinjal S.

description:
Cute and hidden SoMa Bar, reminds me of the NYC nightlife!

This place is semi speak-easy, you are carded at the door and walk upstairs to an elaborate brick decor. It was super modern-esque and very trendy. The drinks are good! not too strong but the bartenders pour generously. Also, they have a little VIP-reserved lounge (with stairwells), so if you want something more exclusive where you can look down at the bar, I would suggest booking that. 

Anyways, I ordered the "Something with Vodka" drink which was very good. I would come here again because it's not super packed (yet) and the decor is just too cute (nice antique couches, brick walls, typewriters, and random artwork). Also, if you like the Novela and Local Edition atmosphere, this place is a great alternative and plus it's close to AT&T park!
author: Julia K.

description: This was told to me by Jake the bartender over at Saison. He'd mentioned that it was "interesting". Maybe one of the weirder and more interesting confluence of drinkers I've seen in a while. I think the SOMA/FIdi proximity makes for people gathering from various companies and not folks who would normally drink together. Marina chicks and tech dudes in the same group? Gotta be a company thing. Came here late after seeing a show. Got a couple of drinks before catching the train out of town. Decently mixed though my drink was terribly small while my friend's was huge. $24 for the two is certainly up there in price. I hate to shill but if you're in the area and paying that scratch, Saison definitely has much higher quality alcohol/mixed drinks
author: Kim N.

description:
What a great find!  Did a last minute trip to SF from Napa for a night to change up the scenery and met up with some friends.  A friend recommended this place - and while it got QUITE crowded that Friday --- we had a great time and got lucky in finding seats at the bar.  

-- Great tator tots
-- Mens enjoyed several rounds of beers
-- I enjoyed a very delicious orange juice soda

Definitely going back for the cocktails and tots.
author: Arry Y.

description:
Really, really impressed.  It's hard to find a way to do "mixology" without bald face pretension.  This was a very refreshing atmosphere, likely due to the location.  It's possible that Giants fans are simply the most democratizing rabble imaginable - no matter the environment, they sort of shut down the hipster too-cool-for-school vibe in any scenario. So plus one on the location to make it a better crowd of good people.

*&* I doubt it *was* the Giants fans that poured in about 3/4 the way through our visit.....  The owner (I think) & the staff were professional, on the ball, and cheerful... no disdain, and certainly no "I know better than you what you like", which is a constant    problem with this "movement".  It's likely they still just considered themselves noble bartenders crafting high end cocktails.  They even seemed to deconstruct the "silly drink name" list, quite well, showing a bit of coy sass and good natured aplomb - obviously not taking themselves too seriously.

The barkeep that tended to us was friendly but professional without being curt during her 4 or 5 person deep crush....  as busy as it got, she was able to converse, keep up with drinks, and still provide "service", in the lost and traditional sense of the word.

I guess that's why I enjoyed my experience so much - this place is obviously about hospitality, and that's all too rare nowadays.  Perusing their website after the fact, I see them actually use the concept as a hallmark of their mission... and it's lovely to see.  As a hotel guy, me and friends joke that the problem with modern hospitality is that there's none of it.

It's really refreshing to find a corner of this city where good-natured service and professional hospitality isn't just an operational decision, but a way of life.  Good on you guys. I'll be back.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: New bar by the previous manager at gitane. If you want craft cocktails next to the giants stadium or at&t park, alchemist is the only place.  Drinks and space is epic, very similar but better than local edition. Huge space, tons of room.
author: Paul C.

description:
Stopped by Alchemist last Saturday around 11:30 and shut it down. I'm all about positivity, so let's start with the pros: 

1) Pro doorman with nothing but a great attitude, no hassle getting in;
2) Drinks were tasty, strong and reasonably priced.

Now for the not-so-much:
1) The interior. I don't see the resemblance to Local Edition that everyone else talks about - this is much more open, lofty and multi-level. Having said that, it's a somewhat generic look. Compared to say, Wilson & Wilson or Blind Barber in Culver City, I felt like Alchemist lacked a "wow!" factor.
2) Four bartenders for a place this size is ridic. Install a satellite bar near the front and hire more servers.
3) I'm all for inclusiveness, but having said that, it wouldn't hurt to be a bit more selective in regard to who gets admitted. There were some embarrassingly sloppy drunk people stumbling all over and bumping into people; shouldn't happen at a place like this.

Ultimately, Alchemist needs to figure out what it is. Is it a speakeasy? A lounge? A wannabe club? Until it does, there are quite a few other places your time might be better spent at.
author: Sebastian L.

description:
20s style speakeasy interior + signature drinks and drafts + super friendly&fun staff = my favorite bar in SOMA!
The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming on weekdays, while on Friday and Saturday it gets really busy and fun. Since the space is very big and open its an ideal spot to get to know new people or meet your local SOMA friends.
author: Marina Z.

description: Nice little spot on 2nd floor.  Went there on a Wednesday evening so it wasn't too crowded.  Although the place is big enough that it seems like an alright place to be with more people.  For the amount of different mixer bottles laid out on the bar, they didn't seem to have a huge selection of whiskeys and brown liquors.  Cool stuff though.
author: Kyle I.

description:
The ambiance and decor is very old speakeasy and very nicely made. It reminded me of a scene from Merlin or Frankenstein with the brick walls and copper piping. The place is quite spacious and not crowded. There is no cover.

The cocktails were all delicious and I like how they have nonalcoholic cocktails as well. Both of the nonalcoholic cocktails were very good, but I favor the habanero one. I had alcoholic options as well...I just don't remember...
author: Dorris W.

description: Very clean bathrooms and the lighting is darker than Woodbury. The bar area seemed small and when they're busy, it can take a while to get some drinks.
author: Julie L.

description: Wow, this place has really livened up since the last few times I've been here. I LOVE that the atmosphere is a lot more fun now, with good music playing at a louder volume, friendly/fun bartenders, and a decent looking crowd. I forgot how convenient this location is (as it's right in SoMa), and I'll for sure be returning more frequently now that they've upped their game.
author: Diana K.

description:
What a kick-ass awesome bar literally next door to where we live.

So much better than district! Excellent bar-tenders, I would go back here every week :D
author: Akshaya M.

description:
Reminds me of a Bourbon and Branch.

Speakeasy decor
Yummy drinks, but long wait
Even though it's more spacious, it gets stuffy very easily in here

Came here last Friday at 11, only to find out that they were closing at 11:30 instead of their regular time since they were scheduled for a PG&E power outage. weak.
author: Kristen C.

description:
Is ShrubDown one word or two?  Because that's basically what I have to say about this place.  Can't wait to try the next version of the ShrubDown.

The Alchemist has become a work happy hour place for us even though it's not really that close to our work.  I'll let that speak for how much we like the place.  We can always find a comfy space to hang out.  The bar snacks are always delicious and everyone seems to have a good time.  

i love the exposed brick walls and the general atmosphere.  I'm sure youl'll find me (and my co-workers) here again!
author: Jenn M.

description:
This is a place for serious drinkers. None of the beer, shots, lets get shit faced (no offense to beer drinkers, shots shooters, or shit facers), but more on the "Oh you fancy huh?" vibe. Don't get me wrong, I love it. I love the decor, and the vibe, and the discreteness of the entrance way. Plus, the space is pretty large, even if the bar is small in comparison.

Definitely looking for the next chance to come back!
author: Jessica H.

description: We were visitors from out of town and was recommended this place. Great ambiance for a group of friends, maybe not so much for a date? It's a loud place. They don't serve fireballs here, but order the Ancho shots! It's their better verision of fireball.
author: Jessica A.

description:
By far one of the best bars I've been to in the SOMA. This place is sort of hidden above the restaurant Root but just look for the yellow lantern/lights outside. Subtle but once you see it, you can't miss it.

I was here for their NYE party and then came back when my new job hosted a 'new hire' happy hour here. Our group of 50 got excellent service and all of the drinks were so original and tasty. I had a taste of a few but I'm a beer/liquor man myself. The ambiance of the place is casual and there is plenty of room to stand around with your friends/coworkers. There is shuffle board left of the bar if that tickles your fancy as well. Make no mistake, this is not your typical lounge. They're not a club by any means.

From my experience, there are not a lot of places like this around SOMA. If you are looking for a nice place to just have a drink and chat with friends then i suggest this place.
author: edward k.

description: Great speak-easy bar. It gets really loud, but it's pretty spacious and there are a good amount of seats.
author: April Y.

description: Great bar and physical space.  Cocktail menu is small but has the bases covered in a way that will keep most people happy.  Knowledgeable friendly staff, cool interior and location.
author: Darin E.

description: This is a cool spot with great drinks! They have happy hour Monday thru Friday from 5-8. If you like vodka you have to try the drink "Something with Vodka". It's similar to a Moscow Mule and it's super refreshing!
author: Ashley N.

description: a great, usually quiet, roomy upstairs lounge. even after a Giants game it's not super crowded. great cocktail menu, helpful bartenders. a nice place to hang after work, a little more upscale than Woodbury's next door.
author: Bob U.

description:
This place is super crack'n! If you're looking for a great place to hang out post-baseball game, or with friends "just because", this is the place for you.

It has a young-person vibe, great for the business-minded city-dwelling young professionals. They have a small lounge you can reserve for a private party. In the corner they have a shuffle-board that is great if you are on a date.

They play old black and white movies on the walls, and there is plenty of room to stand or sit if you want. There is a full bar, so order whatever you like and the bartenders (who are experienced and good at what they do) will set you up well. :)
author: Andy M.

description:
There are several things that make me a HUGE fan of this bar.  Number 1 I was able to reserve an area for my company of 40 people 4 days before the day. Nothing like a last minute pre-game party!


Communication with Stephani was quick, productive and efficient she helped us preorder food that was on the table by 6:10pm just as the party arrived, she made she that every member of my team had a drink in hand.

The food from Root was good and quickly eaten followed by more drink provided by Stephani.  Great bar and the service was awesome.  

One thing that could be improved is the doorman, I understand that there are rules I would recommend that the doorman find a way to communcate them without making your patrons angry or uncomfortable.

Thank you Stephani and the Alchemist Team for making our evening a success!!
author: Dionne M.

description: Tip: This place is probably amazing for work week happy hours/if you get there on the early side on Fri/Sat night. I came here for a friend's birthday on a Saturday night and arrived around 10 pm. It wasn't very crowded at all at that point, and has great ambiance, available street parking, and the "something with vodkahh" drink was really good. Fast forward a couple hours later, and the place is wall-to-wall packed. Like most bars, plan ahead to get the experience you want, but this place is best served on the chill side.
author: Mel G.

description:
Went to the opening night party, although they've been open for about a week I think.  Nice space, fun decor, good drinks, strange crowd. 

Beer selection is kind of slim, so if you're with people who aren't into cocktails this may not be the place for you.  They do, however, have the champagne of beers so you know, enjoy the high life!

will be interested to see how this place develops regulars, will it be a neighborhood hang, or more of the out of town/caltrain crowd?

Side note you can make a reservation online (I think at least a day in advance) for a private seating area which looks very nice.
author: Alex K. W.

description:
Definitely my new favorite local bar! Only a half block walk from my place, this bar has it all really. Good drinks, bartenders, and decor. 

The bar is upstairs (would be nice for the ladies wearing heels if they had an elevator). Loft like feel with brick wall and exposed pipes. Nice couches and seating area. Kinda freaky films projected on the walls ... Would be nice if those weren't as creepy.

Good menu of drinks. I'm sure they can make a drink to your liking if none of the ones on the menu suit you. 

Best thing about it is that it is not very crowded and there is plenty of space. Lets hope that lasts for a while ...
author: Daniel K.

description:
Came here for a birthday party that unfortunately coincided with a wedding after-party, meaning the place was packed! It took decades to get my drink, but the Somethin' with Vodka was delicious, and the place had a cool vibe, with the black-and-white movies showing on the walls and the little tables around to rest drinks on. 

As the night progressed, the wedding party filtered out and the place became much more chill. It'd definitely be a good place to come back on a less popular night.
author: Ivana J.

description:
Nice new place. Very clean and open, dark, modern feel. 

The drinks were high end and tasty - and being able to order tater tots from downstairs earns a star from me. It wasn't packed when I went, which is nice, but I imagine as more people find out about it, it'll fill up (if that's what you're looking for).
author: Shanee B.
